stagedir.dir: Enter Ferdinand, King of Navarre, Berowne, Longaville, and Dumaine.

line.recite: “Item, That no woman shall come within a mile of my court”—Hath this been proclaim’d?

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Four days ago.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Let’s see the penalty.

line.recite: “Item, If any man be seen to talk with a woman within the term of three years, he shall endure such public shame as the rest of the court can possible devise.”

speech.line: This article, my liege, yourself must break,
For well you know here comes in embassy
The French king’s daughter with yourself to speak—
A maid of grace and complete majesty—
About surrender up of Aquitaine
To her decrepit, sick, and bedred father;
Therefore this article is made in vain,
Or vainly comes th’ admired Princess hither.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What say you, lords? Why, this was quite forgot.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: So study evermore is overshot:
While it doth study to have what it would,
It doth forget to do the thing it should;
And when it hath the thing it hunteth most,
’Tis won as towns with fire—so won, so lost.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We must of force dispense with this decree,
She must lie here on mere necessity.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Necessity will make us all forsworn
Three thousand times within this three years’ space;
For every man with his affects is born,
Not by might mast’red, but by special grace.
If I break faith, this word shall speak for me:
I am forsworn “on mere necessity.”
So to the laws at large I write my name,
And he that breaks them in the least degree
Stands in attainder of eternal shame.
Suggestions are to other as to me;
But I believe, although I seem so loath,
I am the last that will last keep his oath.
But is there no quick recreation granted?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ay, that there is. Our court you know is haunted
With a refined traveller of Spain,
A man in all the world’s new fashion planted,
That hath a mint of phrases in his brain;
One who the music of his own vain tongue
Doth ravish like enchanting harmony;
A man of complements, whom right and wrong
Have chose as umpeer of their mutiny.
This child of fancy, that Armado hight,
For interim to our studies shall relate,
In high-borne words, the worth of many a knight
From tawny Spain, lost in the world’s debate.
How you delight, my lords, I know not, I,
But I protest I love to hear him lie,
And I will use him for my minstrelsy.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Armado is a most illustrious wight,
A man of fire-new words, fashion’s own knight.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Costard the swain and he shall be our sport,
And so to study three years is but short.

stagedir.dir: Enter a Constable Dull with a letter, with Costard.

line.recite: “Great deputy, the welkin’s vicegerent, and sole dominator of Navarre, my soul’s earth’s god, and body’s fost’ring patron”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Not a word of Costard yet.

line.recite: “So it is, besieged with sable-colored melancholy, I did commend the black oppressing humor to the most wholesome physic of thy health-giving air; and as I am a gentleman, betook myself to walk: the time When? About the sixt hour, when beasts most graze, birds best peck, and men sit down to that nourishment which is called supper: so much for the time When. Now for the ground Which? Which, I mean, I walk’d upon: it is ycliped thy park. Then for the place Where? Where, I mean, I did encounter that obscene and most prepost’rous event that draweth from my snow-white pen the ebon-colored ink which here thou viewest, beholdest, surveyest, or seest. But to the place Where? It standeth north-north-east and by east from the west corner of thy curious-knotted garden. There did I see that low-spirited swain, that base minnow of thy mirth”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Me?

line.recite: “that shallow vassal”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Still me?

line.recite: “sorted and consorted, contrary to thy established proclaimed edict and continent canon; which with—O, with—but with this I passion to say wherewith”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: With a wench.

line.recite: “For Jaquenetta (so is the weaker vessel called), which I apprehended with the aforesaid swain, I keep her as a vessel of thy law’s fury, and shall, at the least of thy sweet notice, bring her to trial. Thine, in all complements of devoted and heart-burning heat of duty,
Don Adriano de Armado.”

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: This is not so well as I look’d for, but the best that ever I heard.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ay, the best for the worst. But, sirrah, what say you to this?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Sir, I confess the wench.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Did you hear the proclamation?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I do confess much of the hearing it, but little of the marking of it.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: It was proclaim’d a year’s imprisonment to be taken with a wench.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I was taken with none, sir, I was taken with a damsel.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Well, it was proclaim’d damsel.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: This was no damsel neither, sir, she was a virgin.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: It is so varied too, for it was proclaim’d virgin.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: If it were, I deny her virginity; I was taken with a maid.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: This maid will not serve your turn, sir.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: This maid will serve my turn, sir.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Sir, I will pronounce your sentence: you shall fast a week with bran and water.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I had rather pray a month with mutton and porridge.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And Don Armado shall be your keeper.
My Lord Berowne, see him delivered o’er,
And go we, lords, to put in practice that
Which each to other hath so strongly sworn.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit grows melancholy?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A great sign, sir, that he will look sad.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Why, sadness is one and the self-same thing, dear imp.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: No, no, O Lord, sir, no.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: How canst thou part sadness and melancholy, my tender juvenal?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough signior.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Why tough signior? Why tough signior?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Why tender juvenal? Why tender juvenal?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I spoke it tender juvenal as a congruent epitheton appertaining to thy young days, which we may nominate tender.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: And I tough signior as an appertinent title to your old time, which we may name tough.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Pretty and apt.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: How mean you, sir? I pretty, and my saying apt? Or I apt, and my saying pretty?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Thou pretty, because little.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: And therefore apt, because quick.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Speak you this in my praise, master?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: In thy condign praise.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: I will praise an eel with the same praise.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: What? That an eel is ingenious?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: That an eel is quick.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I do say thou art quick in answers; thou heat’st my blood.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: I am answer’d, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I love not to be cross’d.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: He speaks the mere contrary, crosses love not him.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I have promised to study three years with the Duke.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: You may do it in an hour, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Impossible.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: How many is one thrice told?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I am ill at reck’ning, it fitteth the spirit of a tapster.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I confess both, they are both the varnish of a complete man.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Then I am sure you know how much the gross sum of deuce-ace amounts to.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: It doth amount to one more than two.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Which the base vulgar do call three.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: True.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here is three studied ere ye’ll thrice wink; and how easy it is to put “years” to the word “three,” and study three years in two words, the dancing horse will tell you.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: A most fine figure!

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: To prove you a cipher.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I will hereupon confess I am in love; and as it is base for a soldier to love, so am I in love with a base wench. If drawing my sword against the humor of affection would deliver me from the reprobate thought of it, I would take Desire prisoner, and ransom him to any French courtier for a new devis’d cur’sy. I think scorn to sigh; methinks I should outswear Cupid. Comfort me, boy: what great men have been in love?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Hercules, master.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear boy, name more; and, sweet my child, let them be men of good repute and carriage.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Sampson, master; he was a man of good carriage, great carriage, for he carried the town gates on his back like a porter; and he was in love.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: O well-knit Sampson, strong-jointed Sampson! I do excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst me in carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was Sampson’s love, my dear Moth?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A woman, master.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Of what complexion?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of the four.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Of the sea-water green, sir.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Is that one of the four complexions?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: As I have read, sir, and the best of them too.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Green indeed is the color of lovers; but to have a love of that color, methinks Sampson had small reason for it. He surely affected her for her wit.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: It was so, sir, for she had a green wit.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: My love is most immaculate white and red.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Most maculate thoughts, master, are mask’d under such colors.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Define, define, well-educated infant.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: My father’s wit and my mother’s tongue assist me!

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sweet invocation of a child, most pretty and pathetical!

speech.speaker: MOTH.

line.recite: If she be made of white and red,
Her faults will ne’er be known,
For blush in cheeks by faults are bred,
And fears by pale white shown:
Then if she fear, or be to blame,
By this you shall not know,
For still her cheeks possess the same
Which native she doth owe.

speech.line: A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of white and red.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Is there not a ballet, boy, of the King and the Beggar?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: The world was very guilty of such a ballet some three ages since, but I think now ’tis not to be found; or if it were, it would neither serve for the writing nor the tune.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I will have that subject newly writ o’er, that I may example my digression by some mighty president. Boy, I do love that country girl that I took in the park with the rational hind Costard. She deserves well.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: To be whipt; and yet a better love than my master.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sing, boy, my spirit grows heavy in love.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: And that’s great marvel, loving a light wench.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I say, sing.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Forbear till this company be past.

stagedir.dir: Enter Clown Costard, Constable Dull, and Wench Jaquenetta.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offenses ere thou be pardoned.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Well, sir, I hope when I do it I shall do it on a full stomach.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I am more bound to you than your fellows, for they are but lightly rewarded.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Take away this villain, shut him up.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Come, you transgressing slave, away.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Let me not be pent up, sir; I will fast, being loose.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: No, sir, that were fast and loose; thou shalt to prison.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Well, if ever I do see the merry days of desolation that I have seen, some shall see.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: What shall some see?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Nay, nothing, Master Moth, but what they look upon. It is not for prisoners to be too silent in their words, and therefore I will say nothing. I thank God I have as little patience as another man, and therefore I can be quiet.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Princess of France with three attending Ladies (Rosaline, Maria, Katherine) and three Lords, one named Boyet.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: All pride is willing pride, and yours is so.
Who are the votaries, my loving lords,
That are vow-fellows with this virtuous Duke?

speech.speaker: 1. FR. LORD.
speech.line: Lord Longaville is one.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Know you the man?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I know him, madam; at a marriage-feast,
Between Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir
Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnized
In Normandy, saw I this Longaville,
A man of sovereign parts, peerless esteem’d,
Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms;
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
The only soil of his fair virtue’s gloss,
If virtue’s gloss will stain with any soil,
Is a sharp wit match’d with too blunt a will,
Whose edge hath power to cut, whose will still wills
It should none spare that come within his power.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Some merry mocking lord belike, is’t so?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: They say so most that most his humors know.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Such short-liv’d wits do wither as they grow.
Who are the rest?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: The young Dumaine, a well-accomplish’d youth,
Of all that virtue love for virtue loved;
Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill;
For he hath wit to make an ill shape good,
And shape to win grace though he had no wit.
I saw him at the Duke Alanson’s once,
And much too little of that good I saw
Is my report to his great worthiness.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Another of these students at that time
Was there with him, if I have heard a truth.
Berowne they call him, but a merrier man,
Within the limit of becoming mirth,
I never spent an hour’s talk withal.
His eye begets occasion for his wit,
For every object that the one doth catch
The other turns to a mirth-moving jest,
Which his fair tongue, conceit’s expositor,
Delivers in such apt and gracious words
That aged ears play truant at his tales,
And younger hearings are quite ravished,
So sweet and voluble is his discourse.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: God bless my ladies! Are they all in love,
That every one her own hath garnished
With such bedecking ornaments of praise?

speech.speaker: 1. FR. LORD.
speech.line: Here comes Boyet.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Fair Princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: “Fair” I give you back again, and “welcome” I have not yet. The roof of this court is too high to be yours, and welcome to the wide fields too base to be mine.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: I will be welcome then—conduct me thither.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Hear me, dear lady: I have sworn an oath.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Our Lady help my lord! He’ll be forsworn.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Why, will shall break it, will, and nothing else.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Your ladyship is ignorant what it is.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise,
Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance.
I hear your Grace hath sworn out house-keeping:
’Tis deadly sin to keep that oath, my lord,
And sin to break it.
But pardon me, I am too sudden bold;
To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming,
And suddenly resolve me in my suit.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Madam, I will, if suddenly I may.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: You will the sooner, that I were away,
For you’ll prove perjur’d if you make me stay.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I know you did.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: How needless was it then
To ask the question?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: You must not be so quick.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: ’Tis long of you that spur me with such questions.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Your wit’s too hot, it speeds too fast, ’twill tire.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: What time a’ day?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: The hour that fools should ask.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Now fair befall your mask!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Fair fall the face it covers!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: And send you many lovers!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Amen, so you be none.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Nay then will I be gone.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Madam, your father here doth intimate
The payment of a hundred thousand crowns,
Being but the one half of an entire sum
Disbursed by my father in his wars.
But say that he, or we, as neither have,
Receiv’d that sum, yet there remains unpaid
A hundred thousand more, in surety of the which
One part of Aquitaine is bound to us,
Although not valued to the money’s worth.
If then the King your father will restore
But that one half which is unsatisfied,
We will give up our right in Aquitaine,
And hold fair friendship with his Majesty.
But that, it seems, he little purposeth:
For here he doth demand to have repaid
A hundred thousand crowns, and not demands,
On payment of a hundred thousand crowns,
To have his title live in Aquitaine;
Which we much rather had depart withal,
And have the money by our father lent,
Than Aquitaine, so gelded as it is.
Dear Princess, were not his requests so far
From reason’s yielding, your fair self should make
A yielding ’gainst some reason in my breast,
And go well satisfied to France again.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: You do the King my father too much wrong,
And wrong the reputation of your name,
In so unseeming to confess receipt
Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I do protest I never heard of it;
And, if you prove it, I’ll repay it back,
Or yield up Aquitaine.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: We arrest your word.
Boyet, you can produce acquittances
For such a sum from special officers
Of Charles his father.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Satisfy me so.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: So please your Grace, the packet is not come
Where that and other specialties are bound:
Tomorrow you shall have a sight of them.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: It shall suffice me; at which interview
All liberal reason I will yield unto.
Mean time receive such welcome at my hand
As honor (without breach of honor) may
Make tender of to thy true worthiness.
You may not come, fair Princess, within my gates,
But here without you shall be so receiv’d
As you shall deem yourself lodg’d in my heart,
Though so denied fair harbor in my house.
Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell.
Tomorrow shall we visit you again.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Sweet health and fair desires consort your Grace!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thy own wish wish I thee in every place.

stagedir.dir: Exit with Longaville, Dumaine, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: That last is Berowne, the merry madcap lord.
Not a word with him but a jest.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: And every jest but a word.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Two hot sheeps, marry.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: And wherefore not ships?
No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: You sheep, and I pasture: shall that finish the jest?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: So you grant pasture for me.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Not so, gentle beast.
My lips are no common, though several they be.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Belonging to whom?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: To my fortunes and me.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Good wits will be jangling, but, gentles, agree:
This civil war of wits were much better used
On Navarre and his book-men, for here ’tis abused.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: If my observation (which very seldom lies),
By the heart’s still rhetoric, disclosed with eyes,
Deceive me not now, Navarre is infected.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: With what?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: With that which we lovers entitle “affected.”

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Your reason?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Why, all his behaviors did make their retire
To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire:
His heart like an agot with your print impressed,
Proud with his form, in his eye pride expressed;
His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see,
Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be;
All senses to that sense did make their repair,
To feel only looking on fairest of fair:
Methought all his senses were lock’d in his eye,
As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy,
Who tend’ring their own worth from where they were glass’d,
Did point you to buy them, along as you pass’d;
His face’s own margent did quote such amazes
That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.
I’ll give you Aquitaine and all that is his,
And you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Come to our pavilion—Boyet is dispos’d.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: But to speak that in words which his eye hath disclos’d.
I only have made a mouth of his eye,
By adding a tongue which I know will not lie.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Thou art an old love-monger and speakest skillfully.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: He is Cupid’s grandfather, and learns news of him.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Then was Venus like her mother, for her father is but grim.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Do you hear, my mad wenches?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: What then, do you see?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Ay, our way to be gone.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: You are too hard for me.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Warble, child, make passionate my sense of hearing.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: “Concolinel.”

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years, take this key, give enlargement to the swain, bring him festinately hither. I must employ him in a letter to my love.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: How meanest thou? Brawling in French?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: No, my complete master, but to jig off a tune at the tongue’s end, canary to it with your feet, humor it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometime through the throat, as if you swallow’d love with singing love, sometime through the nose, as if you snuff’d up love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o’er the shop of your eyes; with your arms cross’d on your thin-bellied doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away: these are complements, these are humors, these betray nice wenches that would be betray’d without these; and make them men of note—do you note?—men that most are affected to these.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: How hast thou purchased this experience?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: By my penny of observation.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: But O—but O—

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: “The hobby-horse is forgot.”

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Call’st thou my love “hobby-horse”?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: No, master, the hobby-horse is but a colt,
and your love perhaps a hackney.—
But have you forgot your love?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Almost I had.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Negligent student, learn her by heart.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: By heart and in heart, boy.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: And out of heart, master; all those three I will prove.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: What wilt thou prove?

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: A man, if I live; and this, “by, in, and without,” upon the instant: by heart you love her, because your heart cannot come by her; in heart you love her, because your heart is in love with her; and out of heart you love her, being out of heart that you cannot enjoy her.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I am all these three.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: And three times as much more—

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: A most acute juvenal, volable and free of grace!
By thy favor, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face:
Most rude melancholy, valor gives thee place.
My herald is return’d.

stagedir.dir: Enter Page Moth and Clown Costard.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: My sweet ounce of man’s flesh, my incony Jew!

Now will I look to his remuneration. Remuneration! O, that’s the Latin word for three farthings: three farthings—remuneration. “What’s the price of this inkle?”—“One penny.”—“No, I’ll give you a remuneration”: why, it carries it. Remuneration: why, it is a fairer name than French crown! I will never buy and sell out of this word.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, and I, forsooth, in love! I, that have been love’s whip,
A very beadle to a humorous sigh,
A critic, nay, a night-watch constable,
A domineering pedant o’er the boy,
Than whom no mortal so magnificent!
This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy,
This senior-junior, giant-dwarf, Dan Cupid,
Regent of love-rhymes, lord of folded arms,
Th’ anointed sovereign of sighs and groans,
Liege of all loiterers and malecontents,
Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces,
Sole imperator and great general
Of trotting paritors (O my little heart!),
And I to be a corporal of his field,
And wear his colors like a tumbler’s hoop!
What! I love, I sue, I seek a wife—
A woman, that is like a German clock,
Still a-repairing, ever out of frame,
And never going aright, being a watch,
But being watch’d that it may still go right!
Nay, to be perjur’d, which is worst of all;
And among three to love the worst of all,
A whitely wanton with a velvet brow,
With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes;
Ay, and, by heaven, one that will do the deed
Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard.
And I to sigh for her, to watch for her,
To pray for her, go to! It is a plague
That Cupid will impose for my neglect
Of his almighty dreadful little might.
Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue, groan:
Some men must love my lady, and some Joan.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Was that the King that spurr’d his horse so hard
Against the steep-up rising of the hill?

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: I know not, but I think it was not he.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Whoe’er ’a was, ’a show’d a mounting mind.
Well, lords, today we shall have our dispatch;
On Saturday we will return to France.
Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush
That we must stand and play the murderer in?

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice,
A stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot,
And thereupon thou speak’st the fairest shoot.

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: What, what? First praise me, and again say no?
O short-liv’d pride! Not fair? Alack for woe!

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: Yes, madam, fair.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Nay, never paint me now;
Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow.
Here (good my glass), take this for telling true:
Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

speech.speaker: FOR.
speech.line: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: See, see, my beauty will be sav’d by merit.
O heresy in fair, fit for these days!
A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.
But come, the bow: now mercy goes to kill,
And shooting well is then accounted ill.
Thus will I save my credit in the shoot:
Not wounding, pity would not let me do’t;
If wounding, then it was to show my skill,
That more for praise than purpose meant to kill.
And out of question so it is sometimes:
Glory grows guilty of detested crimes,
When for fame’s sake, for praise, an outward part,
We bend to that the working of the heart;
As I for praise alone now seek to spill
The poor deer’s blood, that my heart means no ill.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty
Only for praise’ sake, when they strive to be
Lords o’er their lords?

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Only for praise—and praise we may afford
To any lady that subdues a lord.

line.recite: “By heaven, that thou art fair, is most infallible; true, that thou art beauteous; truth itself, that thou art lovely. More fairer than fair, beautiful than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have commiseration on thy heroical vassal! The magnanimous and most illustrate King Cophetua set eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar Zenelophon; and he it was that might rightly say, Veni, vidi, vici; which to annothanize in the vulgar—O base and obscure vulgar!—videlicet, He came, saw, and overcame: he came, one; saw, two; overcame, three. Who came? The king. Why did he come? To see. Why did he see? To overcome. To whom came he? To the beggar. What saw he? The beggar. Who overcame he? The beggar. The conclusion is victory; on whose side? The king’s. The captive is enrich’d; on whose side? The beggar’s. The catastrophe is a nuptial; on whose side? The king’s; no, on both in one, or one in both. I am the king, for so stands the comparison; thou the beggar, for so witnesseth thy lowliness. Shall I command thy love? I may. Shall I enforce thy love? I could. Shall I entreat thy love? I will. What shalt thou exchange for rags? Robes; for tittles? Titles; for thyself? Me. Thus expecting thy reply, I profane my lips on thy foot, my eyes on thy picture, and my heart on thy every part. Thine, in the dearest design of industry,
Don Adriano de Armado.

speech.line: Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar
’Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey;
Submissive fall his princely feet before,
And he from forage will incline to play.
But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then?
Food for his rage, repasture for his den.”

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter?
What vane? What weathercock? Did you ever hear better?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Else your memory is bad, going o’er it ere-while.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: This Armado is a Spaniard that keeps here in court,
A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport
To the Prince and his book-mates.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Thou fellow, a word.
Who gave thee this letter?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I told you: my lord.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: To whom shouldst thou give it?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: From my lord to my lady.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: From which lord to which lady?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: From my Lord Berowne, a good master of mine,
To a lady of France that he call’d Rosaline.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Who is the shooter? Who is the shooter?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Shall I teach you to know?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Ay, my continent of beauty.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why, she that bears the bow.
Finely put off!

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: My lady goes to kill horns, but if thou marry,
Hang me by the neck if horns that year miscarry.
Finely put on!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Well then I am the shooter.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: And who is your deer?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near.
Finely put on indeed!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes at the brow.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: But she herself is hit lower. Have I hit her now?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that was a man when King Pippen of France was a little boy, as touching the hit it?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: So I may answer thee with one as old, that was a woman when Queen Guinover of Britain was a little wench, as touching the hit it.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And I cannot, cannot, cannot,
And I cannot, another can.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: By my soul, a swain, a most simple clown!
Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down!
O’ my troth, most sweet jests, most incony vulgar wit!
When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely as it were, so fit.
Armado a’ th’ one side—O, a most dainty man!
To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan!
To see him kiss his hand! And how most sweetly ’a will swear!
And his page a’ t’ other side, that handful of wit!
Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit!
Sola, sola!

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Very reverent sport truly, and done in the testimony of a good conscience.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: The deer was (as you know) sanguis, in blood, ripe as the pomewater, who now hangeth like a jewel in the ear of caelo, the sky, the welkin, the heaven, and anon falleth like a crab on the face of terra, the soil, the land, the earth.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Truly, Master Holofernes, the epithites are sweetly varied, like a scholar at the least; but, sir, I assure ye it was a buck of the first head.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: ’Twas not a haud credo, ’twas a pricket.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Most barbarous intimation! Yet a kind of insinuation, as it were in via, in way, of explication; facere, as it were, replication, or rather ostentare, to show, as it were, his inclination, after his undressed, unpolished, uneducated, unpruned, untrained, or rather unlettered, or ratherest unconfirmed fashion, to insert again my haud credo for a deer.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: I said the deer was not a haud credo, ’twas a pricket.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Twice sod simplicity, bis coctus!
O thou monster Ignorance, how deformed dost thou look!

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Sir, he hath never fed of the dainties that are bred in a book;
He hath not eat paper, as it were; he hath not drunk ink; his intellect is not replenished; he is only an animal, only sensible in the duller parts;
And such barren plants are set before us, that we thankful should be—
Which we of taste and feeling are—for those parts that do fructify in us more than he.
For as it would ill become me to be vain, indiscreet, or a fool,
So were there a patch set on learning, to see him in a school:
But omne bene, say I, being of an old father’s mind:
Many can brook the weather that love not the wind.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: You two are book-men: can you tell me by your wit
What was a month old at Cain’s birth, that’s not five weeks old as yet?

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Dictynna, goodman Dull, Dictynna, goodman Dull.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: What is Dictynna?

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: A title to Phoebe, to Luna, to the moon.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: The moon was a month old when Adam was no more,
And raught not to five weeks when he came to five-score.
Th’ allusion holds in the exchange.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: ’Tis true indeed, the collusion holds in the exchange.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: God comfort thy capacity! I say, th’ allusion holds in the exchange.

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: And I say, the pollution holds in the exchange, for the moon is never but a month old; and I say beside that, ’twas a pricket that the Princess kill’d.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal epitaph on the death of the deer? And to humor the ignorant, call I the deer the Princess kill’d a pricket.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Perge, good Master Holofernes, perge, so it shall please you to abrogate squirility.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: I will something affect the letter, for it argues facility.
The preyful Princess pierc’d and prick’d a pretty pleasing pricket;
Some say a sore, but not a sore, till now made sore with shooting.
The dogs did yell: put l to sore, then sorel jumps from thicket,
Or pricket sore, or else sorel; the people fall a-hooting.
If sore be sore, then L to sore makes fifty sores o’ sorel:
Of one sore I an hundred make by adding but one more L.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: A rare talent!

speech.speaker: DULL.
speech.line: If a talent be a claw, look how he claws him with a talent.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: This is a gift that I have, simple; simple, a foolish extravagant spirit, full of forms, figures, shapes, objects, ideas, apprehensions, motions, revolutions. These are begot in the ventricle of memory, nourish’d in the womb of pia mater, and delivered upon the mellowing of occasion. But the gift is good in those in whom it is acute, and I am thankful for it.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Sir, I praise the Lord for you, and so may my parishioners, for their sons are well tutor’d by you, and their daughters profit very greatly under you. You are a good member of the commonwealth.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Mehercle, if their sons be ingenious, they shall want no instruction; if their daughters be capable, I will put it to them: but vir sapit qui pauca loquitur. A soul feminine saluteth us.

stagedir.dir: Enter Jaquenetta and the Clown Costard.

line.recite: “If love make me forsworn, how shall I swear to love?
Ah, never faith could hold, if not to beauty vowed!
Though to myself forsworn, to thee I’ll faithful prove;
Those thoughts to me were oaks, to thee like osiers bowed.
Study his bias leaves, and makes his book thine eyes,
Where all those pleasures live that art would comprehend.
If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice;
Well learned is that tongue that well can thee commend,
All ignorant that soul that sees thee without wonder;
Which is to me some praise that I thy parts admire.
Thy eye Jove’s lightning bears, thy voice his dreadful thunder,
Which, not to anger bent, is music and sweet fire.
Celestial as thou art, O, pardon love this wrong,
That sings heaven’s praise with such an earthly tongue.”

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: You find not the apostraphus, and so miss the accent. Let me supervise the canzonet.

Here are only numbers ratified, but for the elegancy, facility, and golden cadence of poesy, caret. Ovidius Naso was the man. And why indeed “Naso,” but for smelling out the odoriferous flowers of fancy, the jerks of invention? Imitari is nothing: so doth the hound his master, the ape his keeper, the tired horse his rider. But, damosella virgin, was this directed to you?

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Ay, sir, from one Monsieur Berowne, one of the strange queen’s lords.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: I will overglance the superscript: “To the snow-white hand of the most beauteous Lady Rosaline.” I will look again on the intellect of the letter, for the nomination of the party

to the person written unto: “Your ladyship’s in all desired employment, Berowne.” Sir Nathaniel, this Berowne is one of the votaries with the King, and here he hath framed a letter to a sequent of the stranger queen’s, which accidentally, or by the way of progression, hath miscarried. Trip and go, my sweet, deliver this paper into the royal hand of the King; it may concern much. Stay not thy compliment; I forgive thy duty. Adieu.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Good Costard, go with me. Sir, God save your life!

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Have with thee, my girl.

scene.line: Sir, I do invite you too, you shall not say me nay: pauca verba. Away, the gentles are at their game, and we will to our recreation.

stagedir.dir: Enter Berowne with a paper in his hand, alone.

scene.line: Shot, by heaven! Proceed, sweet Cupid, thou hast thump’d him with thy bird-bolt under the left pap. In faith, secrets!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What, Longaville, and reading! Listen, ear.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Now in thy likeness, one more fool appear!

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Ay me, I am forsworn!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Why, he comes in like a perjure, wearing papers.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: In love, I hope—sweet fellowship in shame.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: One drunkard loves another of the name.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Am I the first that have been perjur’d so?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I could put thee in comfort: not by two that I know.
Thou makest the triumphery, the corner-cap of society,
The shape of love’s Tyburn that hangs up simplicity.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: I fear these stubborn lines lack power to move.
O sweet Maria, empress of my love,
These numbers will I tear, and write in prose!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, rhymes are guards on wanton Cupid’s hose:
Disfigure not his shop.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: This same shall go.
This is the liver-vein, which makes flesh a deity,
A green goose a goddess; pure, pure idolatry.
God amend us, God amend! We are much out a’ th’ way.

scene.line: “All hid, all hid,” an old infant play.
Like a demigod here sit I in the sky,
And wretched fools’ secrets heedfully o’er-eye.
More sacks to the mill! O heavens, I have my wish!
Dumaine transformed! Four woodcocks in a dish!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: O most divine Kate!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O most profane coxcomb!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: By heaven, the wonder in a mortal eye!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: By earth, she is not, corporal, there you lie.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Her amber hairs for foul hath amber coted.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: An amber-color’d raven was well noted.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: As upright as the cedar.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Stoop, I say,
Her shoulder is with child.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: As fair as day.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Ay, as some days, but then no sun must shine.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: O that I had my wish!

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: And I had mine!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And mine too, good Lord!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Amen, so I had mine. Is not that a good word?

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: I would forget her, but a fever she
Reigns in my blood, and will rememb’red be.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: A fever in your blood! Why then incision
Would let her out in saucers. Sweet misprision!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Once more I’ll read the ode that I have writ.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Once more I’ll mark how love can vary wit.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: You would for paradise break faith and troth,

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: God bless the King!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What present hast thou there?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Some certain treason.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What makes treason here?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Nay, it makes nothing, sir.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: If it mar nothing neither,
The treason and you go in peace away together.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: I beseech your Grace let this letter be read:
Our person misdoubts it; ’twas treason, he said.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Berowne, read it over.
Where hadst thou it?

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Of Costard.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Where hadst thou it?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Of Dun Adramadio, Dun Adramadio.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How now, what is in you? Why dost thou tear it?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: A toy, my liege, a toy; your Grace needs not fear it.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: It did move him to passion, and therefore let’s hear it.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: It is Berowne’s writing, and here is his name.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Sweet lords, sweet lovers, O, let us embrace!
As true we are as flesh and blood can be.
The sea will ebb and flow, heaven show his face;
Young blood doth not obey an old decree.
We cannot cross the cause why we were born;
Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What, did these rent lines show some love of thine?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Did they, quoth you? Who sees the heavenly Rosaline,
That (like a rude and savage man of Inde),
At the first op’ning of the gorgeous east,
Bows not his vassal head, and strooken blind,
Kisses the base ground with obedient breast?
What peremptory eagle-sighted eye
Dares look upon the heaven of her brow,
That is not blinded by her majesty?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What zeal, what fury, hath inspir’d thee now?
My love (her mistress) is a gracious moon,
She (an attending star) scarce seen a light.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Berowne.
O, but for my love, day would turn to night!
Of all complexions the cull’d sovereignty
Do meet as at a fair in her fair cheek,
Where several worthies make one dignity,
Where nothing wants that want itself doth seek.
Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues—
Fie, painted rhetoric! O, she needs it not.
To things of sale a seller’s praise belongs:
She passes praise, then praise too short doth blot.
A wither’d hermit, fivescore winters worn,
Might shake off fifty, looking in her eye:
Beauty doth varnish age, as if new born,
And gives the crutch the cradle’s infancy.
O, ’tis the sun that maketh all things shine!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: By heaven, thy love is black as ebony.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Is ebony like her? O wood divine!
A wife of such wood were felicity.
O, who can give an oath? Where is a book?
That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack,
If that she learn not of her eye to look:
No face is fair that is not full so black.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: O paradox! Black is the badge of hell,
The hue of dungeons, and the school of night;
And beauty’s crest becomes the heavens well.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Devils soonest tempt, resembling spirits of
O, if in black my lady’s brows be deck’d,
It mourns that painting and usurping hair
Should ravish doters with a false aspect:
And therefore is she born to make black fair.
Her favor turns the fashion of the days,
For native blood is counted painting now;
And therefore red, that would avoid dispraise,
Paints itself black, to imitate her brow.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: To look like her are chimney-sweepers black.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: And since her time are colliers counted bright.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And Ethiops of their sweet complexion crack.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Dark needs no candles now, for dark is light.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Your mistresses dare never come in rain,
For fear their colors should be wash’d away.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: ’Twere good yours did; for, sir, to tell you plain,
I’ll find a fairer face not wash’d today.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I’ll prove her fair, or talk till doomsday here.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: No devil will fright thee then so much as she.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Look, here’s thy love,
my foot and her face see.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, if the streets were paved with thine eyes,
Her feet were much too dainty for such tread!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: O vile! Then as she goes what upward lies
The street should see as she walk’d overhead.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: But what of this, are we not all in love?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, nothing so sure, and thereby all forsworn.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then leave this chat, and, good Berowne, now prove
Our loving lawful, and our faith not torn.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Ay marry, there—some flattery for this evil.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: O, some authority how to proceed;
Some tricks, some quillets, how to cheat the devil.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Some salve for perjury.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, ’tis more than need.
Have at you then, affection’s men-at-arms.
Consider what you first did swear unto:
To fast, to study, and to see no woman—
Flat treason ’gainst the kingly state of youth.
Say, can you fast? Your stomachs are too young,
And abstinence engenders maladies.
(And where that you have vow’d to study, lords,
In that each of you have forsworn his book,
Can you still dream and pore and thereon look?
For when would you, my lord, or you, or you,
Have found the ground of study’s excellence
Without the beauty of a woman’s face?
From women’s eyes this doctrine I derive:
They are the ground, the books, the academes,
From whence doth spring the true Promethean fire.
Why, universal plodding poisons up
The nimble spirits in the arteries,
As motion and long-during action tires
The sinowy vigor of the traveller.
Now for not looking on a woman’s face,
You have in that forsworn the use of eyes,
And study too, the causer of your vow.
For where is any author in the world
Teaches such beauty as a woman’s eye?
Learning is but an adjunct to ourself,
And where we are, our learning likewise is.
Then when ourselves we see in ladies’ eyes,
With ourselves,
Do we not likewise see our learning there?)
O, we have made a vow to study, lords,
And in that vow we have forsworn our books.
For when would you, my liege, or you, or you,
In leaden contemplation have found out
Such fiery numbers as the prompting eyes
Of beauty’s tutors have enrich’d you with?
Other slow arts entirely keep the brain;
And therefore, finding barren practicers,
Scarce show a harvest of their heavy toil;
But love, first learned in a lady’s eyes,
Lives not alone immured in the brain,
But with the motion of all elements,
Courses as swift as thought in every power,
And gives to every power a double power,
Above their functions and their offices.
It adds a precious seeing to the eye:
A lover’s eyes will gaze an eagle blind.
A lover’s ear will hear the lowest sound,
When the suspicious head of theft is stopp’d.
Love’s feeling is more soft and sensible
Than are the tender horns of cockled snails.
Love’s tongue proves dainty Bacchus gross in taste.
For valor, is not Love a Hercules,
Still climbing trees in the Hesperides?
Subtile as Sphinx, as sweet and musical
As bright Apollo’s lute, strung with his hair.
And when Love speaks, the voice of all the gods
Make heaven drowsy with the harmony.
Never durst poet touch a pen to write
Until his ink were temp’red with Love’s sighs:
O then his lines would ravish savage ears
And plant in tyrants mild humility.
From women’s eyes this doctrine I derive:
They sparkle still the right Promethean fire;
They are the books, the arts, the academes,
That show, contain, and nourish all the world,
Else none at all in aught proves excellent.
Then fools you were these women to forswear,
Or keeping what is sworn, you will prove fools.
For wisdom’s sake, a word that all men love,
Or for love’s sake, a word that loves all men,
Or for men’s sake, the authors of these women,
Or women’s sake, by whom we men are men,
Let us once lose our oaths to find ourselves,
Or else we lose ourselves to keep our oaths.
It is religion to be thus forsworn:
For charity itself fulfills the law,
And who can sever love from charity?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Saint Cupid, then! And, soldiers, to the field!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Advance your standards, and upon them, lords;
Pell-mell, down with them! But be first advis’d,
In conflict that you get the sun of them.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Now to plain-dealing, lay these glozes by:
Shall we resolve to woo these girls of France?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And win them too; therefore let us devise
Some entertainment for them in their tents.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: First, from the park let us conduct them thither;
Then homeward every man attach the hand
Of his fair mistress. In the afternoon
We will with some strange pastime solace them,
Such as the shortness of the time can shape,
For revels, dances, masks, and merry hours
Forerun fair Love, strewing her way with flowers.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Away, away, no time shall be omitted
That will be time, and may by us be fitted.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Sow’d cockle reap’d no corn,
And justice always whirls in equal measure:
Light wenches may prove plagues to men forsworn;
If so, our copper buys no better treasure.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Pedant Holofernes, the Curate Sir Nathaniel, and Dull.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: They have been at a great feast of languages, and stol’n the scraps.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: O, they have liv’d long on the alms-basket of words. I marvel thy master hath not eaten thee for a word, for thou art not so long by the head as honorificabilitudinitatibus: thou art easier swallow’d than a flap-dragon.

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Peace, the peal begins.

speech.speaker: ARM.
PRIN.
speech.line: Sweet hearts, we shall be rich ere we depart,
If fairings come thus plentifully in.
A lady wall’d about with diamonds!
Look you what I have from the loving King.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Madam, came nothing else along with that?

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Nothing but this? Yes, as much love in rhyme
As would be cramm’d up in a sheet of paper,
Writ a’ both sides the leaf, margent and all,
That he was fain to seal on Cupid’s name.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: That was the way to make his godhead wax,
For he hath been five thousand year a boy.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Ay, and a shrowd unhappy gallows too.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: You’ll ne’er be friends with him, ’a kill’d your sister.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: He made her melancholy, sad, and heavy,
And so she died. Had she been light, like you,
Of such a merry, nimble, stirring spirit,
She might ’a’ been a grandam ere she died.
And so may you; for a light heart lives long.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: What’s your dark meaning, mouse, of this light word?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: A light condition in a beauty dark.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: We need more light to find your meaning out.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: You’ll mar the light by taking it in snuff;
Therefore I’ll darkly end the argument.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Look what you do, you do it still i’ th’ dark.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: So do not you, for you are a light wench.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Indeed I weigh not you, and therefore light.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: You weigh me not? O, that’s you care not for me.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Great reason: for past care is still past cure.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Well bandied both, a set of wit well played.
But, Rosaline, you have a favor too?
Who sent it? And what is it?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I would you knew.
And if my face were but as fair as yours,
My favor were as great: be witness this.
Nay, I have verses too, I thank Berowne;
The numbers true, and, were the numb’ring too,
I were the fairest goddess on the ground.
I am compar’d to twenty thousand fairs.
O, he hath drawn my picture in his letter!

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Any thing like?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Much in the letters, nothing in the praise.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Beauteous as ink—a good conclusion.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Fair as a text B in a copy-book.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Ware pencils ho! Let me not die your debtor,
My red dominical, my golden letter:
O that your face were not so full of o’s!

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: A pox of that jest! And I beshrow all shrows.
But, Katherine, what was sent to you from fair Dumaine?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Madam, this glove.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Did he not send you twain?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Yes, madam, and moreover
Some thousand verses of a faithful lover.
A huge translation of hypocrisy,
Vildly compiled, profound simplicity.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: This, and these pearls, to me sent Longaville.
The letter is too long by half a mile.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: I think no less. Dost thou not wish in heart
The chain were longer and the letter short?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Ay, or I would these hands might never part.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: We are wise girls to mock our lovers so.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: They are worse fools to purchase mocking so.
That same Berowne I’ll torture ere I go.
O that I knew he were but in by th’ week!
How I would make him fawn, and beg, and seek,
And wait the season, and observe the times,
And spend his prodigal wits in bootless rhymes,
And shape his service wholly to my device,
And make him proud to make me proud that jests!
So pair-taunt-like would I o’ersway his state
That he should be my fool and I his fate.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: None are so surely caught, when they are catch’d,
As wit turn’d fool; folly, in wisdom hatch’d,
Hath wisdom’s warrant and the help of school,
And wit’s own grace to grace a learned fool.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: The blood of youth burns not with such excess
As gravity’s revolt to wantonness.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Folly in fools bears not so strong a note
As fool’ry in the wise, when wit doth dote,
Since all the power thereof it doth apply
To prove, by wit, worth in simplicity.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: The trumpet sounds, be mask’d; the maskers come.

stagedir.dir: Enter Blackamoors with music, the Boy Moth with a speech, the King and the rest of the Lords disguised as Russians.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: What would these strangers? Know their minds, Boyet.
If they do speak our language, ’tis our will
That some plain man recount their purposes.
Know what they would.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: What would you with the Princess?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Nothing but peace, and gentle visitation.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: What would they, say they?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Nothing but peace, and gentle visitation.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why, that they have, and bid them so be gone.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: She says, you have it, and you may be gone.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Say to her we have measur’d many miles,
To tread a measure with her on this grass.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: They say that they have measur’d many a mile
To tread a measure with you on this grass.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: It is not so. Ask them how many inches
Is in one mile: if they have measured many,
The measure then of one is eas’ly told.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: If to come hither you have measur’d miles,
And many miles, the Princess bids you tell
How many inches doth fill up one mile.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Tell her, we measure them by weary steps.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: She hears herself.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: How many weary steps
Of many weary miles you have o’ergone
Are numb’red in the travel of one mile?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: We number nothing that we spend for you;
Our duty is so rich, so infinite,
That we may do it still without accompt.
Vouchsafe to show the sunshine of your face,
That we (like savages) may worship it.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: My face is but a moon, and clouded too.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Blessed are clouds, to do as such clouds do!
Vouchsafe, bright moon, and these thy stars, to shine
(Those clouds removed) upon our watery eyne.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: O vain petitioner! Beg a greater matter,
Thou now requests but moonshine in the water.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then in our measure do but vouchsafe one change.
Thou bid’st me beg; this begging is not strange.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Play, music, then! Nay, you must do it soon.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: White-handed mistress, one sweet word with thee.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Honey, and milk, and sugar: there is three.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Nay then two treys, and if you grow so nice,
Metheglin, wort, and malmsey; well run, dice!
There’s half a dozen sweets.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Seventh sweet, adieu.
Since you can cog, I’ll play no more with you.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: One word in secret.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Let it not be sweet.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Thou grievest my gall.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Gall! Bitter.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Therefore meet.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: What, was your vizard made without a tongue?

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: I know the reason, lady, why you ask.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: O for your reason! Quickly, sir, I long!

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: You have a double tongue within your mask,
And would afford my speechless vizard half.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: “Veal,” quoth the Dutchman. Is not veal a calf?

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: A calf, fair lady!

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: No, a fair lord calf.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Let’s part the word.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: No, I’ll not be your half.
Take all and wean it, it may prove an ox.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Look how you butt yourself in these sharp mocks!
Will you give horns, chaste lady? Do not so.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Then die a calf, before your horns do grow.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: One word in private with you ere I die.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Bleat softly then, the butcher hears you cry.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Twenty adieus, my frozen Muscovits.
Are these the breed of wits so wondered at?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Tapers they are, with your sweet breaths puff’d out.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Well-liking wits they have—gross gross, fat fat.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: O poverty in wit, kingly-poor flout!
Will they not (think you) hang themselves tonight?
Or ever but in vizards show their faces?
This pert Berowne was out of count’nance quite.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: They were all in lamentable cases!
The King was weeping-ripe for a good word.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Berowne did swear himself out of all suit.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Dumaine was at my service, and his sword:
“No point,” quoth I; my servant straight was mute.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Lord Longaville said I came o’er his heart,
And trow you what he call’d me?

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Qualm, perhaps.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Yes, in good faith.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Go, sickness as thou art!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Well, better wits have worn plain statute-caps.
But will you hear? The King is my love sworn.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: And quick Berowne hath plighted faith to me.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: And Longaville was for my service born.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Dumaine is mine, as sure as bark on tree.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Madam, and pretty mistresses, give ear:
Immediately they will again be here
In their own shapes; for it can never be
They will digest this harsh indignity.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Will they return?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: They will, they will, God knows,
And leap for joy, though they are lame with blows:
Therefore change favors, and when they repair,
Blow like sweet roses in this summer air.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: How blow? How blow? Speak to be understood.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Fair ladies mask’d are roses in their bud;
Dismask’d, their damask sweet commixture shown,
Are angels vailing clouds, or roses blown.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Avaunt, perplexity! What shall we do,
If they return in their own shapes to woo?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Good madam, if by me you’ll be advis’d,
Let’s mock them still, as well known as disguis’d.
Let us complain to them what fools were here,
Disguis’d like Muscovites, in shapeless gear;
And wonder what they were, and to what end
Their shallow shows and prologue vildly penn’d,
And their rough carriage so ridiculous,
Should be presented at our tent to us.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Ladies, withdraw; the gallants are at hand.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Whip to our tents, as roes run o’er land.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Fair sir, God save you! Where’s the Princess?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Gone to her tent. Please it your Majesty
Command me any service to her thither?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: That she vouchsafe me audience for one word.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: I will, and so will she, I know, my lord.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: See where it comes! Behavior, what wert thou
Till this madman show’d thee? And what art thou now?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: All hail, sweet madam, and fair time of day!

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: “Fair” in “all hail” is foul, as I conceive.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Conster my speeches better, if you may.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Then wish me better, I will give you leave.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We came to visit you, and purpose now
To lead you to our court; vouchsafe it then.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: This field shall hold me, and so hold your vow:
Nor God, nor I, delights in perjur’d men.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Rebuke me not for that which you provoke:
The virtue of your eye must break my oath.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: You nickname virtue; vice you should have spoke,
For virtue’s office never breaks men’s troth.
Now by my maiden honor, yet as pure
As the unsallied lily, I protest,
A world of torments though I should endure,
I would not yield to be your house’s guest:
So much I hate a breaking cause to be
Of heavenly oaths, vow’d with integrity.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: O, you have liv’d in desolation here,
Unseen, unvisited, much to our shame.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Not so, my lord, it is not so, I swear;
We have had pastimes here and pleasant game,
A mess of Russians left us but of late.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How, madam? Russians?

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Ay, in truth, my lord;
Trim gallants, full of courtship and of state.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Madam, speak true. It is not so, my lord.
My lady (to the manner of the days)
In courtesy gives undeserving praise.
We four indeed confronted were with four
In Russian habit; here they stay’d an hour,
And talk’d apace; and in that hour, my lord,
They did not bless us with one happy word.
I dare not call them fools; but this I think,
When they are thirsty, fools would fain have drink.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: This jest is dry to me. Gentle sweet,
Your wits makes wise things foolish. When we greet,
With eyes best seeing, heaven’s fiery eye,
By light we lose light; your capacity
Is of that nature that to your huge store
Wise things seem foolish, and rich things but poor.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: This proves you wise and rich, for in my eye—

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I am a fool, and full of poverty.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: But that you take what doth to you belong,
It were a fault to snatch words from my tongue.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: O, I am yours, and all that I possess!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: All the fool mine?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: I cannot give you less.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Which of the vizards was it that you wore?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Where? When? What vizard? Why demand you this?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: There then, that vizard, that superfluous case,
That hid the worse, and show’d the better face.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We were descried, they’ll mock us now downright.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Let us confess and turn it to a jest.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Amaz’d, my lord? Why looks your Highness sad?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Help, hold his brows, he’ll sound! Why look you pale?
Sea-sick, I think, coming from Muscovy.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Thus pour the stars down plagues for perjury.
Can any face of brass hold longer out?
Here stand I, lady, dart thy skill at me,
Bruise me with scorn, confound me with a flout,
Thrust thy sharp wit quite through my ignorance,
Cut me to pieces with thy keen conceit;
And I will wish thee never more to dance,
Nor never more in Russian habit wait.
O, never will I trust to speeches penn’d,
Nor to the motion of a schoolboy’s tongue,
Nor never come in vizard to my friend,
Nor woo in rhyme, like a blind harper’s song!
Taffata phrases, silken terms precise,
Three-pil’d hyperboles, spruce affection,
Figures pedantical—these summer flies
Have blown me full of maggot ostentation.
I do forswear them, and I here protest,
By this white glove (how white the hand, God knows!),
Henceforth my wooing mind shall be express’d
In russet yeas and honest kersey noes.
And to begin, wench, so God help me law!
My love to thee is sound, sans crack or flaw.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Sans “sans,” I pray you.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Yet I have a trick
Of the old rage. Bear with me, I am sick;
I’ll leave it by degrees. Soft, let us see—
Write “Lord have mercy on us” on those three:
They are infected, in their hearts it lies;
They have the plague, and caught it of your eyes.
These lords are visited; you are not free,
For the Lord’s tokens on you do I see.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: No, they are free that gave these tokens to us.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Our states are forfeit, seek not to undo us.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: It is not so, for how can this be true,
That you stand forfeit, being those that sue?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Peace, for I will not have to do with you.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Nor shall not, if I do as I intend.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Speak for yourselves, my wit is at an end.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Teach us, sweet madam, for our rude transgression
Some fair excuse.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: The fairest is confession.
Were not you here but even now, disguis’d?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Madam, I was.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: And were you well advis’d?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I was, fair madam.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: When you then were here,
What did you whisper in your lady’s ear?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: That more than all the world I did respect her.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: When she shall challenge this, you will reject her.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Upon mine honor, no.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Peace, peace, forbear:
Your oath once broke, you force not to forswear.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Despise me when I break this oath of mine.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: I will, and therefore keep it. Rosaline,
What did the Russian whisper in your ear?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Madam, he swore that he did hold me dear
As precious eyesight, and did value me
Above this world; adding thereto, moreover,
That he would wed me, or else die my lover.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: God give thee joy of him! The noble lord
Most honorably doth uphold his word.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What mean you, madam? By my life, my troth,
I never swore this lady such an oath.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: By heaven, you did; and to confirm it plain,
You gave me this: but take it, sir, again.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: My faith and this the Princess I did give;
I knew her by this jewel on her sleeve.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Pardon me, sir, this jewel did she wear,
And Lord Berowne (I thank him) is my dear.
What? Will you have me, or your pearl again?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Neither of either; I remit both twain.
I see the trick an’t; here was a consent,
Knowing aforehand of our merriment,
To dash it like a Christmas comedy.
Some carry-tale, some please-man, some slight zany,
Some mumble-news, some trencher-knight, some Dick,
That smiles his cheek in years and knows the trick
To make my lady laugh when she’s dispos’d,
Told our intents before; which once disclos’d,
The ladies did change favors; and then we,
Following the signs, woo’d but the sign of she.
Now, to our perjury to add more terror,
We are again forsworn, in will and error.
Much upon this ’tis;
Welcome, pure wit, thou part’st a fair fray.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: O Lord, sir, they would know
Whether the three Worthies shall come in or no.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: What, are there but three?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: No, sir, but it is vara fine,
For every one pursents three.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: And three times thrice is nine.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Not so, sir, under correction, sir, I hope it is not so.
You cannot beg us, sir, I can assure you, sir, we know what we know.
I hope, sir, three times thrice, sir—

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Is not nine.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Under correction, sir, we know whereuntil it doth amount.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: By Jove, I always took three threes for nine.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: O Lord, sir, it were pity you should get your living by reck’ning, sir.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: How much is it?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: O Lord, sir, the parties themselves, the actors, sir, will show whereuntil it doth amount. For mine own part, I am, as they say, but to parfect one man in one poor man, Pompion the Great, sir.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Art thou one of the Worthies?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: It pleas’d them to think me worthy of Pompey the Great; for mine own part, I know not the degree of the Worthy, but I am to stand for him.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Go bid them prepare.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: We will turn it finely off, sir; we will take some care.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Anointed, I implore so much expense of thy royal sweet breath as will utter a brace of words.

stagedir.dir: Converses apart with the King, and delivers him a paper.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Doth this man serve God?

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Why ask you?

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: ’A speaks not like a man of God his making.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: That is all one, my fair, sweet, honey monarch; for I protest, the schoolmaster is exceeding fantastical, too too vain, too too vain: but we will put it (as they say) to fortuna de la guerra. I wish you the peace of mind, most royal couplement.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: “I Pompey am”—

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: You lie, you are not he.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: “I Pompey am”—

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: With libbard’s head on knee.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Well said, old mocker. I must needs be friends with thee.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: “I Pompey am, Pompey surnam’d the Big”—

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: “The Great.”

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: It is “Great,” sir.
“Pompey surnam’d the Great,
That oft in field with targe and shield did make my foe to sweat,
And travelling along this coast, I here am come by chance,
And lay my arms before the legs of this sweet lass of France.”
If your ladyship would say, “Thanks, Pompey,” I had done.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Great thanks, great Pompey.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: ’Tis not so much worth; but I hope I was perfect. I made a little fault in “Great.”

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: My hat to a halfpenny, Pompey proves the best Worthy.

stagedir.dir: Enter Curate Sir Nathaniel for Alexander.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: “When in the world I liv’d, I was the world’s commander;
By east, west, north, and south, I spread my conquering might.
My scutcheon plain declares that I am Alisander”—

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Your nose says, no, you are not; for it stands too right.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Your nose smells “no” in this, most tender-smelling knight.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: The conqueror is dismay’d. Proceed, good Alexander.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: “When in the world I liv’d, I was the world’s commander”—

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Most true, ’tis right; you were so, Alisander.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Pompey the Great—

speech.speaker: COST.
