speech.line: Your servant, and Costard.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Take away the conqueror, take away Alisander.

speech.speaker: COST.
HOL.
speech.line: “Great Hercules is presented by this imp,
Whose club kill’d Cerberus, that three-headed canus;
And when he was a babe, a child, a shrimp,
Thus did he strangle serpents in his manus.
Quoniam he seemeth in minority,
Ergo I come with this apology.”
Keep some state in thy exit, and vanish.
“Judas I am”—

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: A Judas!

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Not Iscariot, sir.
“Judas I am, ycliped Machabeus.”

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Judas Machabeus clipt is plain Judas.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: A kissing traitor. How art thou prov’d Judas?

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: “Judas I am”—

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: The more shame for you, Judas.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: What mean you, sir?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: To make Judas hang himself.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: Begin, sir, you are my elder.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Well follow’d: Judas was hang’d on an elder.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: I will not be put out of countenance.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Because thou hast no face.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: What is this?

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: A cittern-head.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: The head of a bodkin.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: A death’s face in a ring.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: The face of an old Roman coin, scarce seen.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: The pommel of Caesar’s falchion.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: The carv’d-bone face on a flask.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Saint George’s half-cheek in a brooch.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Ay, and in a brooch of lead.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Ay, and worn in the cap of a tooth-drawer. And now forward, for we have put thee in countenance.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: You have put me out of countenance.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: False, we have given thee faces.

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: But you have out-fac’d them all.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: And thou wert a lion, we would do so.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Therefore as he is, an ass, let him go. And so adieu, sweet Jude! Nay, why dost thou stay?

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: For the latter end of his name.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: For the ass to the Jude; give it him. Jud-as, away!

speech.speaker: HOL.
speech.line: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: A light for Monsieur Judas! It grows dark, he may stumble.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Alas, poor Machabeus, how hath he been baited!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Hide thy head, Achilles, here comes Hector in arms.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Though my mocks come home by me, I will now be merry.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Hector was but a Troyan in respect of this.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: But is this Hector?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I think Hector was not so clean-timber’d.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: His leg is too big for Hector’s.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: More calf, certain.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: No, he is best indu’d in the small.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: This cannot be Hector.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: He’s a god or a painter, for he makes faces.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: “The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty,
Gave Hector a gift”—

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: A gilt nutmeg.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: A lemon.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: Stuck with cloves.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: No, cloven.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Peace!—
“The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty,
Gave Hector a gift, the heir of Ilion;
A man so breathed, that certain he would fight, yea,
From morn till night, out of his pavilion.
I am that flower”—

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: That mint.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: That columbine.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sweet Lord Longaville, rein thy tongue.

speech.speaker: LONG.
speech.line: I must rather give it the rein, for it runs against Hector.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Ay, and Hector’s a greyhound.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: The sweet war-man is dead and rotten, sweet chucks, beat not the bones of the buried. When he breathed, he was a man. But I will forward with my device.
Sweet royalty, bestow on me the sense of hearing.

stagedir.dir: Berowne steps forth to whisper to Costard and then returns to his place.

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Speak, brave Hector, we are much delighted.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: I do adore thy sweet Grace’s slipper.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Loves her by the foot.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: He may not by the yard.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: “This Hector far surmounted Hannibal.
The party is gone”—

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Fellow Hector, she is gone; she is two months on her way.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: What meanest thou?

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Faith, unless you play the honest Troyan, the poor wench is cast away. She’s quick, the child brags in her belly already. ’Tis yours.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Dost thou infamonize me among potentates? Thou shalt die.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: Then shall Hector be whipt for Jaquenetta that is quick by him, and hang’d for Pompey that is dead by him.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Most rare Pompey!

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: Renowned Pompey!

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Greater than great, great, great, great Pompey! Pompey the Huge!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Hector trembles.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Pompey is mov’d. More Ates, more Ates! Stir them on, stir them on!

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Hector will challenge him.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Ay, if ’a have no more man’s blood in his belly than will sup a flea.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: By the north pole, I do challenge thee.

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I will not fight with a pole like a Northren man; I’ll slash, I’ll do it by the sword. I bepray you let me borrow my arms again.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Room for the incens’d Worthies!

speech.speaker: COST.
speech.line: I’ll do it in my shirt.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: Most resolute Pompey!

speech.speaker: MOTH.
speech.line: Master, let me take you a button-hole lower. Do you not see Pompey is uncasing for the combat? What mean you? You will lose your reputation.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Gentlemen and soldiers, pardon me, I will not combat in my shirt.

speech.speaker: DUM.
speech.line: You may not deny it; Pompey hath made the challenge.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Sweet bloods, I both may and will.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: What reason have you for’t?

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: The naked truth of it is, I have no shirt; I go woolward for penance.

speech.speaker: BOYET.
speech.line: True, and it was enjoin’d him in Rome for want of linen; since when, I’ll be sworn he wore none but a dishclout of Jaquenetta’s, and that ’a wears next his heart for a favor.

speech.speaker: MARC.
speech.line: God save you, madam!

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Welcome, Marcade,
But that thou interruptest our merriment.

speech.speaker: MARC.
speech.line: I am sorry, madam, for the news I bring
Is heavy in my tongue. The King your father—

speech.speaker: PRIN.
speech.line: Dead, for my life!

speech.speaker: MARC.
speech.line: Even so: my tale is told.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Worthies, away! The scene begins to cloud.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: For mine own part, I breathe free breath. I have seen the day of wrong through the little hole of discretion, and I will right myself like a soldier.
Ay, sweet my lord, and so I take my leave.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: No, madam, we will bring you on your way.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: Our wooing doth not end like an old play:
Jack hath not Gill. These ladies’ courtesy
Might well have made our sport a comedy.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Come, sir, it wants a twelvemonth an’ a day,
And then ’twill end.

speech.speaker: BER.
speech.line: That’s too long for a play.
This side is Hiems, Winter; this Ver, the Spring; the one maintained by the owl, th’ other by the cuckoo. Ver, begin.

speech.speaker: SPRING.
speech.line: When daisies pied, and violets blue,
And lady-smocks all silver-white,
And cuckoo-buds of yellow hue
Do paint the meadows with delight,
The cuckoo then on every tree
Mocks married men; for thus sings he, “Cuckoo;
Cuckoo, cuckoo”—O word of fear,
Unpleasing to a married ear!
When shepherds pipe on oaten straws,
And merry larks are ploughmen’s clocks;
When turtles tread, and rooks and daws,
And maidens bleach their summer smocks,
The cuckoo then on every tree
Mocks married men; for thus sings he, “Cuckoo;
Cuckoo, cuckoo”—O word of fear,
Unpleasing to a married ear!

speech.speaker: WINTER.
speech.line: When icicles hang by the wall,
And Dick the shepherd blows his nail,
And Tom bears logs into the hall,
And milk comes frozen home in pail;
When blood is nipp’d, and ways be foul,
Then nightly sings the staring owl, “Tu-whit, to-who!”—
A merry note,
While greasy Joan doth keel the pot.
When all aloud the wind doth blow,
And coughing drowns the parson’s saw,
And birds sit brooding in the snow,
And Marian’s nose looks red and raw;
When roasted crabs hiss in the bowl,
Then nightly sings the staring owl, “Tu-whit, to-who!”—
A merry note,
While greasy Joan doth keel the pot.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: The words of Mercury are harsh after the songs of Apollo. You that way; we this way.
